comment: Real 1 with Dr. Young is tough but manageable. Three exams and a final, covering vocab/theorems, true/false questions, and proofs straight from the homework. Exams are weighted progressively (lowest 10%, next 15%, then 20%, highest 25%). Weekly homework sets. The proofs you practice there are the exam proofs. Go to class and do the homework.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria

comment: Professor Young is the best professor I have had. His course follows the textbook (which can be found online) and it makes a lot of sense. He has weekly quizzes on Wednesdays that are based on the homework that was due the Friday before. His tests are based off homework and quizzes. LEARN YOUR VOCAB. All in all go to class and you will be fine.

PLEASE READ: This professor is PHENOMENAL when it comes to his lectures, it's very clear he puts in  so much effort in his teaching to help us understand the content in a proficient level! HOWEVER, his tests and grading can be too brutal! Unfortunately, I cannot recommend him if taking tests isn't your strong suit! Perfect lectures, flawed system!

Simply put, this professor makes the content way too difficult to understand when the actual computations of the content is quite easy. His grading is relatively fair, his study guides are nearly irrelevant to any quiz/exam. All his examinations are semi-reflective of his homework and previous quizzes. Would not recommend if you struggle with math.

Professor Young is a standout in the math department at KSU. Informative lectures with examples made his class easy to follow, and the homework, which was a reasonable length, tied in nicely with the material we were learning for any given week. The class is fairly difficult, but professor Young keeps it fair, would recommend this professor.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Young is an incredible professor. He wants you to succeed, and if you give effort to that, show up for his office and ask questions you will. He is kind, smart, and good at lecturing. His class is mostly weighted by the exams, and attendance is not graded but mandatory if you wish to pass. If you wish to learn ODE, take Professor Young
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: I could have gotten a better grade if I studied more. You definitely need to go to class because he tests over information covered in class that was not on the homework. I think he spends a bit too much time explaining the theory behind the math, leaving not a lot of time for examples

Tough grading scale, 90% of your grade is in class quizzes and tests. Quizzes aren't too bad, but the test are fairly hard. The HW preps you pretty well for the course. Good lectures, a but theory heavy but you'll learn alot. No test drops, a small 5 percent curve at the end. You'll free stressed out at times but it's doable.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: The class in general is very difficult but Glenn makes it simpler for one to learn. He gives you all the material that you need to pass this class and it is you fault if you don't work for the passing grade. Take him because he's a great guy who cares about his students' grades and if they understand anything.

His grading scale is amazing for those who are not very good at taking exams. Homework takes up about 40% of the grade and the highest scored test weighs the most out of the rest. His teaching during class is okay though I would've preferred if he went over more practice problems, which you can only get in the homework.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: Professor Young is a skilled professor with exceptional skills in teaching the subject. The homeworks/study guides were not the best representations of the test material. The 40% weight on homework came in clutch because the tests were fairly difficult. He did provide a curve for the tests (mainly because there would be a failing average)
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Hes a good professor, and is nice and his lectures are pretty good. The only issue is he spends way too much time going over theorems and how these formulas are made instead of examples of applying the formulas. The test questions are pretty different than the homework, but he has a friendly grading scale. truthfully I should have passed this class

Very good teacher who handled the virtual shift well. He has easy pop quizzes in class so you have to show up to the virtual meetings. Tests are challenging but he gives extra credit assignments/quizzes.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Great professor. If you take him be prepared to have a homework set due every week and be quizzed on based off the hw. Nothing too bad, the quizzes are pretty straight forward. He does a good job in explaining concepts and cares about his improvement as a professor overall. The midterm and final were pretty tough so make sure you study.
